Speaker: frank
Dialogue: So, what do you do?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I'm studying to be an actress. You?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm a longshoreman.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No, I mean really.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I mean really too. Starting Monday, though, I'm doing something a little more glamorous. Night cashier at a cafeteria.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I don't mean how you make money.   I mean what are you interested in?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Honey - if I had the answer to that one, I bet I'd bore us both to death in half an hour.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Thank God that's over...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Thanks, Mrs. Givings.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'll pass it along!

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Frank!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Hi!

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: She's through there...!  You `bout ready for that drink?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Couple of minutes!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: April, sweetheart.   You were great. I mean it.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Hi. You about ready to leave? I've just got to get this makeup off, then we can go.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well... I guess it wasn't a triumph or anything, was it?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I guess not. I'll be ready in a minute.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Take your time.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Will you do me a favor? Milly and Shep wanted us to go out with them afterwards. Will you say we can't? Say it's because of the baby sitter or something?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, the thing is, I already said that we could. I mean, I just saw them out there and I said we would.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Oh. Then would you mind going out again and saying you were mistaken? That should be simple enough.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't you think that's a little bit rude, April?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Well I'll tell them myself.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Okay. Okay. Take it easy. I'll tell them.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I mean it, baby. You were the only person in that play.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: We just never should've let you get mixed up in the damned thing.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You've studied for Christ's sake.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Could we sort of stop talking about it now?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Sure. I just don't want you feeling bad about it, that's all. Because it's not worth it. I mean, it's bad enough having to live out here among these damn people - what'd you say?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I said yes. All right, Frank. Could you just stop talking now, before you drive me crazy, please?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No, Frank, please don't...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Baby, it's okay...

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Please don't touch me.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: April...

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Why can't you...just... LEAVE ME ALONE!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It strikes me, that there's a considerable amount of bullshit going on here.... And there's one or two things I'd like to clear up. Number one, it's not my fault the play was lousy. Number two, it's sure as hell not my fault you didn't turn out to be an actress, and the sooner you get over that little piece of soap opera the better off we'll both be. Number three, I don't happen to fit the role of dumb, insensitive suburban husband; you've been trying to hang that one on me ever since we moved here. Number four -

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What the hell are you doing?     Come back to the car.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No. Just let me stand here a second.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: April?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Haven't I made it clear I don't particularly want to talk about it?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Okay. Jesus, I'm trying to be nice about this thing.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: How kind of you. How terribly, terribly kind of you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Wait a minute. I don't deserve this.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You're always so wonderfully definite, aren't you, on the subject of what you do and don't deserve?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Wait a minute!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Christ, I wish you'd stayed home tonight!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You know what you are when you're like this? You're sick. I really mean that. You're sick!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: And you know what you are?  You're disgusting.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh, yeah?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Just because you've got me safely in this little trap, you think you can bully me into feeling whatever you want!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You in a trap! You in a trap! Jesus, don't make me laugh!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Yes, me.  Me! Me! Me! Oh, you poor, pathetic little boy  Look at you! Look at you, and tell me how by any stretch of the imagination you can call yourself a man!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't look at me like that, April.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Could we please go home now?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Good morning, Jack.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Nothing good about it, I assure you.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Oh, yes.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You wanted to see me?

Speaker: bandy
Dialogue: Came for you from Toledo this morning.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh, right, sorry. I thought I'd taken care of that...

Speaker: bandy
Dialogue: I'm not prepared to have this conversation again, Frank. You understand?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: ...Absolutely, yes.

Speaker: bandy
Dialogue: These folks in the provinces look up to us, Frank.    We need to be efficient. We can't have this kind of back and forth, and so forth. It's just not efficient. Am I right?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: ...Absolutely, yes, yes...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What was that about?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Toledo. Branch manager wants a revised brochure for the conference on "The Knox 500."  "It's just not efficient."

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Sounds like a real goodie.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I don't even know what the Knox 500 does... Do you?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Don't insult me.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Now, if you'll look in the inactive file under SP-1109 you'll find copies of all the stuff we sent to the agency... and that way we can trace the thing back to its original sources.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: I'm not really hungry.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Good. I'll check on you later.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: Oh?    How's that?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I can show you the ropes. There's an art to survival at Knox. Let me show you what I mean.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: Wow.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Hello Mrs. Jorgensen. Frank Wheeler here. Just wanted to let you know that I've had to send Maureen Grube down to Visual Aides for me. I'll probably need her the rest of the day... Okay? Fine. You too.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: I never even heard of Visual Aides.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: That's because it doesn't exist.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Hi Helen.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Well, thank you... You want some coffee?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Is there something I can do for you, Helen?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I'm sorry to hear that.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: ...I'm so sorry.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Yes.    Of course.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: We'd love to Helen.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: We'd love to.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You know what today is?

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: ...Monday?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's my birthday.      I'm thirty years old today.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: Happy birthday!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Visual Aides.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: ...What-a-joke.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Want to hear a real joke...?

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He was a salesman in Yonkers. Once a year he used to take me into the city for lunch. It was supposed to be a special, life-advice sort of occasion.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: Nice.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Not really... I used to sit there and think, `I hope to Christ I don't end up like you.'

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: I think I kind of lost you...   Your father worked for Knox...?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How `bout some air?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You ever been to Paris?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I've never really been anywhere.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Maybe I'll take you with me.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Frank Wheeler?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Mm?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I think you're the most interesting person I've ever met.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, I guess this wasn't what you had in mind when you went to work this morning?

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: No.   It certainly wasn't.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Sure, here.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: Can I get you a drink or anything?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No thanks, Maureen. Actually, I guess I'd better be cutting out, it's getting kind of late.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: Gee, that's right.   Have you missed your train?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's all right, I'll get the next one.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Frank...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Why are you all dressed up?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: First of all, I missed you all day and I want to say I'm sorry. I'm sorry for the way I've been since that stupid play. I'm sorry for everything and... And I love you... Now wait here till I call you. Okay?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Frank. I have had the most wonderful idea. I've been thinking about it all day.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What's all this about?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You know how much money we have saved...?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What we get for the house...What are you talking about? Where are we going to live?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: ...Paris.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You're serious?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Yes.   What's stopping us?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What's stopping us? Well, I can think of a lot of things. For instance, what kind of a job could I possibly get?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You won't be getting any kind of job, because I will.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh, right.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Don't laugh -- listen a minute! Have you any idea what they pay for secretarial positions in the government agencies in Europe? Embassies and those things.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No, I don't.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I'm serious about this Frank. Do you think I'm kidding or something?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No, I know, I know. I just have a couple of questions, is all. For one thing, do you mind telling me what exactly I'm supposed to be doing while you're out earning all this money?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Don't you see that's the whole idea? You'll be doing what you should've been allowed to do seven years ago. You'll have time, Frank. You'll have time to find out what it is that you actually want to do, and when you figure it out you'll have the time and the freedom to start doing it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Sweetheart, it's just not very realistic, is all.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Well, I happen to think this is unrealistic. I think it's unrealistic for a man with a fine mind to go on working like a dog year after year at a job he can't stand, coming home to a place he can't stand, to a wife who's equally unable to stand the same things.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Listen: we decided to move out here. No one ever forced me to take the job at Knox.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: When I first met you, there was nothing in the world you couldn't do or be.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I was a little wise guy with a big mouth, that's all.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You were not! How can you even say that?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: ...All right... So, I'll have time. And God knows that's appealing. It's very appealing. And I mean, everything you say might make a certain amount of sense, if I had some definite talent maybe. If I were an artist or a writer.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: But Frank, listen to me: It's what you are that's being stifled here. It's what you are that's being denied and denied and denied in this kind of life.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: And what's that?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Don't you know...?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Okay?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Why not...? Why the hell not?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Ah, Franklin. Good to see your shining face.  What's the news?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm moving to Paris.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Right.   And I'm moving to Tangiers.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: ...Intra-company letter to Toledo... Attention B.F. Chalmers, branch manager... With regard to recent and repeated correspondence, this is to advise that the matter has been... very satisfactorily taken in hand, period, paragraph.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Good luck.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: And when does this noble experiment commence?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: September.     October at the outside.

Speaker: ed
Dialogue: Right, yes.

Speaker: vince
Dialogue: Absolutely, absolutely.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: But... I mean, assuming there is a true vocation waiting for you. Wouldn't you be just as likely to discover it here as there?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No... I don't think it's possible to discover anything on the fifteenth floor of the Knox building, and I don't think any of you do either.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: ...All the way to... here.

Speaker: jennifer
Dialogue: But why?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Well, sweetheart. It's a big world out there and we thought maybe we should go see a little bit of it.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: How far is it?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: A long way. We have to take a boat ride over the sea to get there.

Speaker: jennifer
Dialogue: I won't know anyone there.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I know. And neither will I. But remember when you started school? And now look how many friends you have...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You'll never guess what they eat in Paris. You'll never guess...

Speaker: jennifer
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Snails.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: And frog's legs!

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Buddappa banh!     Banh!   Banh!

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: You better get changed, they'll be here soon.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: That what you're wearing?

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Don't you like it?

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: ...No... No. You look great, doll. Guess I better haul ass.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Hiya gang.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Oh those look great.    I'm starving!

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: April, I can't get over it - you look like the cat who ate the canary! Do you have something to tell us? A little bit of news?

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Not to pry or anything.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: I'm not prying. Am I prying?    I didn't mean to.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Actually, we have got some pretty important news.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: We're going to Europe.    To Paris... To live.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: September.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: But what for?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What for? Because we've always wanted to. Because the kids are still young. Because it's beautiful. Shep, you tell her.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: ...It's a great city.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: When did you make this decision?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Oh... about a week ago... its hard to remember. We just suddenly decided to go, that's all.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: About a week ago, and you tell us now!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: We had to get used to the idea.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: So, what's the deal, Frank? You get a job over there, or what?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No. Not exactly.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: What do you mean, `not exactly?'

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Frank won't be doing any kind of a job, because I will.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: And what are you going to do?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm going to study... and I'm going to read and... I suppose I'm going to finally figure out what I want to do with my life.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: ...While she supports you?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yes. While she supports me...   At least in the beginning.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You wouldn't believe what they pay for secretarial work in government agencies over there. NATO and E.C.A. and those places.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: The cost of living is dirt cheap compared to here, so we should be all right.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: The truth is we just need something different.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Gee, it sounds wonderful, kids. I mean it; it really sounds wonderful. We'll certainly miss you, though - won't we, sweetie? Golly.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Paris.   Wow.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: You know what I think?

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Oh God, I'm so relieved. Me too... I was thinking that the whole time.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: What kind of man is going to sit around in his bathrobe picking his nose while his wife works all day?

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: I don't know, Shep.   I just don't know.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Nothing.   I'm just so relieved.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Come on. Don't cry. Please. It's all right. It's going to be all right.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Jesus, their faces! You'd think we'd told them that we were swimming up the Yangtzee river or something.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I felt that way once too.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: The first time you made love to me.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What's up?

Speaker: ed
Dialogue: Bart Pollock is here.

Speaker: vince
Dialogue: He's in Bandy's office.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: ed
Dialogue: Looks like he wants to talk to you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Hey.   Keep my name out of it.

Speaker: bandy
Dialogue: Frank. How are you? You know Bart Pollock?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, we've never met, but -

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: Glad to know you Frank.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You wouldn't have believed this guy.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Wish I saw his face when you told him you were leaving.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: ...Horse's ass.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I think this is them.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You're not late.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You didn't have to do that.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: The time they finish that stretch of road, they'll have to start all over again.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: And you must be John?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Nice to meetcha.   Heard a lot aboutcha.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: They're at a birthday party.     Sorry they couldn't be here.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Don't worry. If I had a certified lunatic coming around the house, I'd probably get the kids out of the way too.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: It's just some sandwiches.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Helen's been talking it up about you people for months.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Who'd like some sherry?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I'd like some sherry. And I'll drink Helen's if she doesn't beat me to it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I think I can do that.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: You a lawyer Frank?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No, I'm not.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I could use a lawyer.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Pop, couldn't you just sit there and eat your wonderful egg salad, and quit horning in?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: If he hits her with it and kills her, that's a criminal case.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: If all he does is break the coffee table and give her a certain amount of aggravation and she decides to go to court over it, that's a civil case.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Ma, how about doing everybody a favor? How about shutting up!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I can look into it.   Maybe recommend someone.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: So, what do you do, Frank?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I work for Knox Business Machines.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: You design the machines?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Nope.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Make `em, sell `em, repair `em?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I sort of help sell them, I guess. I work in the office. Actually, it's sort of a stupid job. I mean there's nothing  you know, interesting about it or anything.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Whaddya do it for then?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Okay, okay, okay  I know it's none of my business. And besides, I know the answer. You want to play house, you got to have a job. You want to play very nice house, very sweet house, then you got to have a job you don't like. Anyone comes along and asks "Whaddya do it for?' he's probably on a four-hour pass from the State funny farm. All agreed...? Ma?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't be. I agree with everything you said, John. We both do. That's why I'm quitting the job in the fall and we're taking off.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: We're moving to Paris.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Did you know about this, Ma...? Wow. How do you feel about that, Ma? The nice young Wheelers are taking off!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How about some fresh air, John?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I hear you're a mathematician.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: You hear wrong.     It's all gone now.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: All gone?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: You know what electrical shock treatments are?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Yes.   Yes I do.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I've had thirty-seven.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: How awful.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: `How awful...' Why, because mathematics is so `interesting?'

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No. Because the shocks must be awful and... well, because it's awful not to be able to do what it is you want to do. I think mathematics are dull.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I like your girl, Frank.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Me too.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: So, what do a couple of people like you have to run away from?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: We're not running.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: And what's in Paris?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: A different way of life.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: So maybe we are running... We're running from the hopeless emptiness of the whole life here.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: The hopeless emptiness? Now, you've said it. Plenty of people are on to the emptiness, but it takes real guts to see the hopelessness... Wow.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You know, he's the first person who seemed to know what we were talking about.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: That's true. Maybe we are just as crazy as he is.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: If being crazy means living life as if it matters then I don't care if we are completely insane.  Do you?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I love you so much.

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: Tell you something, Frank. I'm a little sore at Bandy for the way he's kept you under a bushel all these years. This place okay, for you?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: This is just fine, sir.   Fine.

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: One thing interests me, Frank, and one thing only: selling the electronic computer to the American businessman...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, sir, it sounds exciting.

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: Bart!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Bart...

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: Can't say that I do. Relation of yours?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: My father. He worked at Knox almost twenty years.

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: Earl Wheeler... Earl Wheeler...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No reason you would have heard of him.

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: Well, I'm sure he was a good man.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: There's something I should have mentioned earlier... I'm leaving the firm. In the fall.

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: Another outfit?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No, it's not another outfit --

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: Now look, Frank. Is it a question of money? Because if it is, there's no reason we can't get together on a satisfactory

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I appreciate that, but it's not money. It's more of a personal thing.

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: A personal thing? I see.  Frank... Let me tell you something my father told me... A man only gets a couple chances in life. If he doesn't grab `em by the balls, it won't be long before he finds himself sitting around wondering how he got to be second rate.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I guess so.

Speaker: bart pollock
Dialogue: So, do me a favor... Sleep on it. Discuss it with your wife. Because let's face it: where the hell would any of us be without our wives, anyway?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Knowing what you've got, comma, knowing what you need, comma, Knowing what you can do without, dash. That's inventory control.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: Oh, hi Frank. Working late?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I got to dig myself out here.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: I heard you were getting promoted.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Huh. Yeah, I guess so...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yeah.   Maybe.

Speaker: maureen
Dialogue: I'll just get my coat.

Speaker: jennifer
Dialogue: I'm going to take my doll carriage and my bear and my three Easter rabbits and my giraffe and all my dolls and my doll house.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I thought maybe we'd give the doll house to Madeline.

Speaker: jennifer
Dialogue: No! I don't want to give it to Madeline.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I already explained to you, the big things are going to be hard to pack.

Speaker: jennifer
Dialogue: But Madeline can have my bear and my Easter rabbits -

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No! Just the big things. Look. Wouldn't you rather go outside and play with Michael.

Speaker: jennifer
Dialogue: I don't feel like it.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You've been inside all day.

Speaker: jennifer
Dialogue: I don't feel like it!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Well, I don't feel like explaining everything fifteen times to somebody who's too bored and silly to listen!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I don't believe you. Did something happen today or what?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Nothing happened today that I haven't known about for days and days.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Oh God, Frank, please don't look so dense. Do you mean you haven't guessed or anything?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I'm pregnant, that's all.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What...?   Jesus.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Oh, Frank, I meant to wait until dinner to tell you, but I just - well, I've been pretty sure all week and today I went to the Doctor and now I can't even pretend it's not true.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Jesus... How long?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Ten weeks.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You didn't say anything.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I thought... Oh, I don't know what I thought.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I know you are.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: We don't have to let this stop us. There are things we can do. Remember that girl at school I told you about...? As long as you do it before 12 weeks, it's fine.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Okay.   We'll figure it out.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I love you Frank.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: ...I love you too.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: So, Frank, how's work?   They gonna survive without you?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Actually... Something kinda funny happened the other day. I did some dumb little piece of work to get myself off the hook with Bandy, and suddenly I'm The Bright Young Man.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: That's always the way, isn't it?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's incredible. I knocked this thing off in a couple of minutes and now they want me to join their team of `specialist' salesmen.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Morons.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It'd be funny, if they weren't talking about so much damn money.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: So, you tempted?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, it's kind of ironic, don't you think?

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: She okay?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I thought you turned the job down?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Not yet... It's just an option, that's all. With the money they're talking, things could be different for us here. We could get a better place. Travel.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: So you've made up your mind?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No.   Like I said, it's an option.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: ...And supposing you're right. You make all this money and we have this interesting life here. Won't you still be wasting your life toiling away at a job you find ridiculous? Just like your father.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Maybe we let that be my business.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Your business?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's too hot for this.    I'm going to get wet.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You don't want to go, do you?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Come on, April.   Of course I do.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You don't! Because you've never tried at anything. And if you don't try at anything you can't fail.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What the hell do you    mean I don't try? I support you,     don't I? I pay for this house.     I work ten hours a day at a job    I can't stand.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You don't have to!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Bullshit! I'm not happy about it. But I have the backbone not to run away from my responsibilities!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: It takes backbone to lead the life you want, Frank.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Is it alright with you if I go to the bathroom?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What the hell are you going to do with this?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: And what do you think you're going to do? You're going to stop me?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You're damn right!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Go ahead and try!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Listen. Listen to me. You do this - you do this and I swear to God I'll -

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You'll what? You'll leave me?   Is that a threat, or a promise?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: When did you buy this, April?   I want to know!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You know you really are being melodramatic about the whole thing. As long as it's done in the first twelve weeks, it's perfectly safe.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: That's now April!   Don't I get a say?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Of course you do! It would be for you, Frank, don't you see? So you can have time. Like we talked about.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How can it be for me if the thought makes my stomach turn over?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Then it's for me... Tell me we can have the baby in Paris, Frank. But don't make me stay here. Please.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: We can't have the baby in Paris.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Why not? I don't need everything we have here. I don't care where we live! I mean who made these rules, anyway? The only reason we moved out here was because I got pregnant. Then we had another child to prove the first one wasn't a mistake. I mean how long does it go on?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: All I know is what I feel. And anyone else in their right mind would feel the same way.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: But I've had two children.    Doesn't that count in my favor?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Christ! The fact that you even put it that way! You make it sound like having children is a punishment.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I love my children.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: And you're sure about that?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: What the hell is that supposed to mean?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: April, you just said our daughter was mistake. How do I know you didn't try to get rid of her, or Michael for that matter? How do I know you didn't try to flush our entire fucking family down the toilet?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No that's not true. Of course I didn't.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: But how do I know April?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Stop.   Please just stop, Frank.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: April, a normal woman, a normal sane mother doesn't buy herself a piece of rubber tubing to give herself an abortion so she can, go live out some God damn fantasy.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: ...And the new job's going to pay for that too?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: April if you need a shrink, it'll be paid for. Obviously.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: ...Okay. I guess there isn't much more to say, then, is there?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I guess maybe it was.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I hope so Frank.   I really hope so.

Speaker: receptionist
Dialogue: Thank you for waiting.   Mr. Pollock can see you now.

Speaker: ed
Dialogue: I can't say I'm sorry.

Speaker: vince
Dialogue: Wouldn't have been the same without you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You'd have been sorely missed in the old cubicle, I can tell you that.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: ...Well, the plan always seemed a touch unrealistic, don't you think?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No.   I suppose it isn't.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well, we won't be the only ones glad to hear the news. They'll be celebrating in the secretarial pool.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Hey! Remember the first time you brought us here? You said, it takes a special kind of taste to enjoy Vito's Log Cabin!

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: It's so awful it's kinda nice!

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: That's right!

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: At least Europe's not going anywhere.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Wanna dance?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I don't really feel like it.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: I'll dance!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Think she'll be okay?

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Oh, sure. Give us girls a couple of days and we can get over anything!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Gee...I'm afraid I'm not very...

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Of all the inconsiderate...

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Look - why don't you take Milly home, then go home yourself and that would take care of both sitters. Then Shep can take me home later.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: All right with me.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You'll be alright?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: I'm sorry you're not going away anymore. I know it was important to you.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: It didn't have to be Paris.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: You just wanted out, huh?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I wanted in. I just wanted us to live again.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Sure you are. You're The Wheelers. You're a terrific couple, everyone says so.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I saw a different life. I can't stop seeing it.  No damn use to anyone.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Let me take you somewhere.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No. Please. Here.    Now.    In the back seat.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Don't say that.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: I mean it, I love you.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Please, just be quiet for a minute, then you can take me home.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's beautiful out.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Yes; it's lovely.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You know what today is?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Look, this has been kind of a crazy summer. We've both been under a strain. I mean I know you're upset.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You know I'm not sleeping with you and you want to know why?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Okay. What do you feel like talking about?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Would it be all right if we didn't talk about anything? Can't we just take each day as it comes, and do the best we can, and not feel we have to talk about everything all the time?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I don't think I suggested we talk about everything all the time. My point was, we've both been under a strain and we ought to be trying to help each other as much as we can right now.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Why did you?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Baby, I don't know. I think it was a simple case of wanting to be a man again after all that abortion business. Some kind of neurotic, irrational need to prove something.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No. I don't mean why did you have the girl; I mean why did you tell me about it?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Why don't you say what you feel?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I don't feel anything.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: In other words you don't care what I do or who I fuck or anything?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No; I guess that's right; I don't.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't you see...Don't you see, I want you to care.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Oh, I know you do. And I suppose I would if I loved you. But you see I don't think I do anymore. And I only just figured that out. And that's why I'd just as soon not do any talking right now.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh, now don't give me this shit! You know God damn well you love me!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You think so?!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You know GOD DAMN WELL!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I'm sorry dinner's late. Can I get anyone a refill?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Actually, there's been a change of plans.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I thought maybe it was obvious... April's pregnant.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Hold it a second, Ma.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I'm asking the man a question. If he doesn't want to give me the answer, I'm assuming he'll have sense enough to tell me so.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Suppose we just say that people anywhere aren't very well advised to have babies unless they can afford them.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Okay. Okay; it's a question of money. Money's always a good reason...

Speaker: john
Dialogue: What happened, Frank? You get cold feet, or what? You decide you're better off here after all? You figure it's more comfy here in the old Hopeless Emptiness after all, or --

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Boy!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Now look, I think that's just about enough out of you. I mean, who the hell do you think you are? You come in here and say whatever crazy God damn thing comes into your head and I think it's about time someone told you to keep your God damn -

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Not well, my ass! I don't give a damn if he's sick or well or dead or alive, he should keep his fucking opinions in the fucking insane asylum where they belong!

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Big man you got there, April.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You... fucking..!

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Right... Sorry, sorry, sorry! Okay Ma? Have I said `Sorry' enough times? I am sorry, too. Damn; I bet I'm just about the sorriest bastard I know. Course, get right down to it, I don't have a whole hell of a lot to be glad about, do I?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Okay, okay, don't tell me. Don't tell me; let me guess. I made a Disgusting Spectacle of Myself. Right?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: And everything that man said is True. Right? Isn't that what you're going to say?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Apparently I don't have to.     You're saying it for me.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: But you're wrong.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Why am I wrong?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Because the man is insane. He's fucking insane! Do you know what the definition of insanity is?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: What is it, Frank?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: The inability to relate to another human being. It's the inability to love.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: The in -- the in; the inabil; the inability to --

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No. Wrong. You're not crazy and you do love me; that's the point.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: But I don't. In fact I loathe the sight of you. You're just a boy who made me laugh at a party once and if you come any closer, if you touch me or anything I think I'll scream.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh baby listen --

Speaker: april
Dialogue: What're you going to do now? Are you going to hit me? To show how much you love me?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh, no, don't worry, I can't be bothered! You're not worth the trouble it'd take to hit you. You're not worth the powder it'd take to blow you up. You're an empty --

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Don't come any closer.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: April, listen, I --

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Don't come any closer. Can't I even get away from you in the fucking woods?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: April, listen, I didn't mean that. Honestly; I didn't mean what I said.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Are you still talking? Isn't there any way to stop your talking? I NEED to think. Can't you see that?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Please come back.     What're you doing out here?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Do you want me to scream again, Frank? Because I will, if you say another word! I mean it!

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Would you like scrambled eggs or fried?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh. It doesn't really matter - Uh... scrambled, I guess, if it's easy.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Fine.   I'll have scrambled too.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's kinda nice having breakfast without the kids for a change.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Yes. I thought you'd probably want a good breakfast today. I mean it's kind of an important day for you, isn't it? Isn't this the day you have your conference with Pollock?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yes. That's right, yes.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: I imagine it is a pretty big deal; for them, anyway. What exactly do you think you'll be doing? You never have told me much about it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Haven't I? Well... I think this whole thing is about Knox getting ready to buy up one of these really big computers, bigger than the `500'. Did I tell you about that?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No, I don't believe you did.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, you know -- Basically it's just a...a big, fast adding machine. Only...

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Oh, I see. At least I think I see; yes. It's really sort of -- interesting, isn't it?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, I don't know, it's -- yeah, I guess it is sort of interesting, in a way.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: You should value what you do Frank. You're obviously good at it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Guess I'd better be getting started.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Thank you... I'm glad; I enjoyed it too.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Then you don't -- You don't hate me, or anything?

Speaker: april
Dialogue: No; of course I don't.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Okay, then... So long.

Speaker: april
Dialogue: Hello... Milly? Everything all right? My voice sounds what...?

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Frank? They tell you what happened?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Jesus, Shep. I couldn't even understand half the things he told me. He said the fetus was out before they got her here. He said they had to operate to take out the whatdycallit, the placenta and now she's still bleeding. He said she'd lost a lot of blood before the ambulance came, and now they're trying to stop it, and he said a whole lot of things I didn't get, about capillaries, and he said she's unconscious. Jesus.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: How about sitting down, Frank.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What the hell do I want to sit down for!

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Okay.   Take it easy.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: My God.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Here, have a cigarette.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: She did it to herself, Shep.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: I'll get some coffee.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No.   No.   No.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Try to sit down, Mr. Wheeler.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Sit down Frank.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: ...It was the worst experience of my life. Such wonderful people. Weren't they Shep? Poor April.

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Bart Pollock Associates.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: No. Too many memories, I think. Shep's seen him. In the city.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: shep
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: milly
Dialogue: Okay. We don't have to.     We don't have to.
